newsitem.title: USA: Lehman posts higher profits but lower revenues.
newsitem.headline: Lehman posts higher profits but lower revenues.

text.p: Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc. said Wednesday its profits increased by 8 percent in its fiscal third quarter, although the broker and investment banker failed to expand revenues for the first time in five quarters.
The company said its net income for the three months ended Aug. 31 increased to $77 million, or 60 cents a share, from $71 million, or 52 cents a share, a year ago.

However, Lehman said its net revenues, which represent total revenues less interest expenses, slipped 4 percent to $722 million from $750 million last year. They were also well below the second quarter's $833 million.
Lehman said volatile markets and delayed underwritings were among the key reasons the company failed to extend its streak of quarterly revenue growth.

"Volatile conditions in the debt and equity markets, as well as seasonal softness in several businesses, interrupted the five consecutive quarters of higher revenues we had posted," Chairman Richard Fuld said in a statement.
Lehman also cited the effects of interest rate movements on customer trading volumes and decisions by issuers to delay scheduled underwritings for the decline.

For the nine months, Lehman said its net income soared by 66 percent to $289 million, or $2.28 a share, from $174 million, or $1.27 a share, the year earlier. Net revenues for the three quarters expanded by 9 percent to $2.4 billion from $2.2 billion.
Lehman said in the third quarter its revenues from principal transactions rose to $303 million from $245 million while investment banking revenues fell to $237 million from $251 million.
Commissions revenues fell to $77 million from $116 million while interest and dividend revenues rose to $2.96 billion from $2.83 billion.
However, interest expenses for the quarter rose to $2.86 billion from $2.70 billion, more than offsetting the increase in interest and dividend related revenues.
Other revenues fell to $4 million from $11 million.

Below the revenue line, the picture was somewhat better, with Lehman's return on common equity rising to 9.0 percent from 8.5 percent a year ago. Still, that was well short of the 13.4 percent figure posted in the second quarter.
Lehman's pre-tax margin for the quarter was 16.0 percent, down from the second quarter's 20.2 percent level but up from 14.5 percent a year ago.
"While quarterly revenue was off for a number of market-related and seasonal reasons, it is important to note that our discipline around expenses remained strong," Fuld said.
Total non-interest expenses for the quarter fell to $606 million from $641 million a year ago, a key reason the company was able to improve quarterly net, the company said.
Lehman's stock gained 37.5 cents to $23.375 in afternoon trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
